The classic Celtic folk movement, that of the Helvetii, is described in first-hand detail by Julius Caesar in the first book of his Commentaries on the Gallic War. New scientific methods including isotope analysis and ancient DNA are beginning to provide new data on the mobility of the Celts

title: The subject of Celtic art has been dealt with extensively in a number of general books. The classic text is P. Jacobsthal, Early Celtic Art
which has set the scene for everything which follows, but the most helpful overview, copiously illustrated, is R

which is the essential starting-point; the volume also has an extensive bibliog­ raphy arranged thematically. More recent, thought-provoking studies are contained in D
Technologies of Enchantment? Exploring Celtic Art: 400 bc to ad 100

The archaeology and protohistory of the Dacians is much less accessible
Romania
The Late Iron Age Background to Roman Dacia’

container-title: Rome and the Barbarians in Central and Eastern Europe: 1st Century B.C.–1st Century A.D
title: Roman Dacia: The Making of a Provincial Society

For a very broad over­ view of the protohistory of east Europe

note: Other useful detailed studies include: J. Collis, Oppida: Earliest Towns North of the Alps (Sheffield, 1984); O.-H. Frey, ‘Die Bedeutung der Gallia Cisalpina für die Entstehung der Oppida-Kultur’, in O.-H. Frey and H. Roth
title: The study of oppida has inspired a considerable literature. A readable, simplified account is provided by F
Villages and Coun­ tryside of Celtic Europe: From the Beginnings of the Second Millennium to the End of the First Century bc
Structures d’habitats et fortifications de l’âge du fer en France septentrionale

The most extensive excavation of an oppidum is that of Manching in southern Germany, published in a highly detailed multi-volume monograph series of which the first sets the scene: W

container-title: Quo Vadis? Long-term Research Projects in European Archaeology. Conference held at Schleswig, Schloss Gottorf

title: Einführung und Fundstellenübersicht

Manching—A Celtic Oppidum between Rescue Excava­ tion and Research’
207–21, while for a broad consideration of the results of the programme
Manching Reconsidered: New Perspectives on Set­ tlement Dynamics and Urbanization in Iron Age Central Europe’

note: For the Rhine–Danube area: C. M. Wells, The German Policy of Augustus: An Examination of the Archaeological Evi­ dence (Oxford, 1972); G. Alföldy, Noricum (London, 1974); and A. Mócsy, Pannonia and Upper Moesia: A History of the Middle Danube Provinces of the Roman Empire (London, 1974).
title: Caesar’s conquest of Gaul is dealt with in fine critical detail by C. Goudineau in César et la Gaule (Paris, 1990); and the imme­ diate aftermath is considered in G. Woolf, Becoming Roman: The Origins of Provincial Civilization in Gaul
For Britain: S
Britannia: A History of Roman Britain
The Romanization of Britain: An Essay in Archaeological Interpretation
An Imperial Posses­ sion: Britain in the Roman Empire, 54 bc–ad 409
